description.narrative: People, particularly women and other vulnerable groups, have improved access to responsive and accountable justice and human rights protection mechanisms.

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANI

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
1.1) Pre-trial detention population (as % of total) 1.2) # of criminal justice sector policies, plans, actions and laws informed by data analysis and public consultation inclusive of women and vulnerable groups
2.1) Legal Aid Act revised and enacted 2.2) Legal aid policy guidelines developed and adopted 2.3) % increase in legal awareness, legal assistance and legal aid services 2.4) # of cases resolved through legal aid in prison and police stations 2.5) # of women and children assisted with legal aid services 2.6) # of lawyers contacted in the BA for pro bono representation, and # of cases represented
3.1) % of reports submitted on time to UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures 3.2) % of Universal Periodic Review (UPR) recommendations fully implemented by the Government of Tanzania

comment.narrative:
1.1) 50% of all prisoners are in custody awaiting trial (16,551) 1.2) TBD
2.1) No adequate normative framework on legal aid in place for protection of women and other vulnerable groups 2.2) No adequate normative framework on legal aid in place for protection of women and other vulnerable groups 2.3) Limited number of individuals have access to legal aid services / Limited public legal information campaign 2.4) Though data are not available, perceptions that around 95% of people in prison have not been legally represented 2.5) Women and other vulnerable groups do not benefit from legal aid, particularly in criminal proceedings 2.6) Inefficient pro-bono system
3.1) 30% of reports submitted on time to UPR, treaty bodies and special procedures 3.2) Limited coordination between AGC, CHRAGG and civil society organizations on UPR monitoring

- NCJF Working Group trained on Plea bargaining and non-custodial sentencing - Joint inspection visits to prisons and police holding cells in 10 regions undertaken - 10 laws translated into Kiswahili in a bid to make to break language barrier which has hindered many in accessing justice - Sheria TV established - UPR and Treaty Bodies including CEDAW Committee action plans implemented. - State report on the UPR prepared and submitted by September - UPR report submitted by CHRAGG - At least two (2) investigations are carried out on reported human rights violations by CHRAGG - A Project Document on Strengthened Tanzanian capability to tackle serious and organized crime setting out activities and strategy in detail, including an appropriate results and resources framework and TORs for the implementation team is developed

- There has been tremendous decongestion in prisons as a result of increased awareness on Plea bargaining and non-custodial sentencing amongst NCJF Working Group through capacity building programmes and trainings whereby, NCJF Working Group skills in fast-tracking the process of plea-bargaining and access to legal services in a more effective and efficient manner were enhanced - A total number of 629 inmates were granted relief through nolle prosequi, while 191 cases were referred for further determination in appropriate authority in 10 prisons of Tanga and Coastal regional as a result of realization of increased capacities for accountability and oversight of criminal justice institutions through joint inspection visits to prisons and detention places - Preliminary activities for the establishment of Sheria Television which is expected to bridge the demand for legal education and awareness, especially in the new normal where physical movement is limited, (due to effect of COVID 19) were undertaken. This includes Consultation with a team of technical persons from Tanzania Broadcasting television for advice and technical support and identifying a list of required working tools and their specifications. - 30 laws were translated into Swahili with support of this project by technical persons from the Ministry of constitutional and Legal Affairs, Law Reform Commission of Tanzania, Office of Attorney General and Tanganyika Law Society, building on the directive by the government to translate laws into Kiswahili, as part of formalizing the use of Kiswahili as a language of Court. - The ministry of Constitutional and Legal Affairs was supported to convene interactions and coordination meetings on the implementation of UPR and Treaty Bodies including CEDAW Committee action plans for concerned Government stakeholders at central and local level including Zanzibar. Stakeholders’ consultations were conducted on UPR with state and non-state actors. - A full fledged Project Document on Strengthened Tanzanian capability to tackle serious and organized crime has been developed

-At least one national criminal justice conference and working groups meeting is Coordinated and conducted aiming at enhancing efficiency in investigation and prosecution and the overall functional and operational capacity of the National Criminal Justice Forum (NCJF). -Technical expertise and training to NCJF Working groups on selected priority group on selected priority areas i.e. non-custodial sentencing, legal aid, plea bargaining is provided -Support to meetings of zonal coordination committees to selected regions including quarterly zonal meetings is provided -Provide Technical and logistical support for establishment of legal clinic at the Law School Tanzania (LST). -Provide support on awareness raising and training to justice and law enforcement officers on legal aid for violations of rights, prevention and response to SGBV as well as other critical areas of need. -Provide support to facilitate the Ministry to participate in National events related to Legal Aid. -At least three interactions and coordination meetings on the implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies, including the CEDAW Committee, action plans for concerned government stakeholders at central and local level are organized -Provide support for quarterly coordination meetings and forums between CHRAGG and CSO on human rights issues and assessing the status of human rights in Tanzania. -Project Mid term evaluation conducted

- Two meetings of the National Criminal Justice Forum (NCJF) and thematic working groups were successfully coordinated and conducted by NPS by the support provided by the project.The two meetings conducted during the reporting period came up with proposed interventions relating to effective implementation of plea-bargaining procedures including training for NPS staff. - In order to enhance the capacity of Prosecutors to investigate and prosecute cases and administer plea bargaining for purposes of decongesting prisons,a training of 40 Regional and District Prosecutors Officers (RPOs and DPOs) on Plea Bargaining was conducted and this helped to assist the RPOs and DPOs to fully understand the mechanisms and enhance their skills in fast-tracking the process of plea-bargaining and access to legal services in a more effective and efficient manner -The project also supported scaling up of legal aid coordination mechanisms to five more regions. Legal aid inter-sectoral committees were established in five regions and one meeting of existing LAIC was held in Arusha It is through these meetings that feedback was received to the effect that the due to improved coordination, the quality of services to indigent populations has improved. - The Law School Tanzania (LST) was supported to establish a legal clinic - There has been an increase of awareness on legal and human rights among Simiyu Community as support was extended to conduct awareness raising and capacity building training for local government leaders in Simiyu, a region where GBV incident rate is quite high. In this regard, more than seven hundred (700) women leaders and members of the peace and security committees in the region were empowered with knowledge of human rights and women rights, particularly those related to family and land rights. - The project through responsible department facilitated discussions on the development of the Second NHRAP at various levels both in Tanzania Mainland and Zanzibar. - A project mid term evaluation was conducted

1. Support provided to operationalize the NCJF Secretariat and at least one training conducted to the Secretariat to coordinate and monitor implementation of NCJF actions. 2. Guidelines and tools for effectiveness of NCJF, including SOP for meetings, information sharing protocols between justice institutions are developed and in use 3. At least one national conference on criminal justice is conducted 4. Support development of the National Prosecution Service Five-year Strategic Plan (2019 – 2023) 5. At least two vehicles procured as a logistical support to the DPP and CHRAGG In facilitating the monitoring and inspection of places of detention across the country. 6. legal aid code of conduct for service providers developed, launched and disseminated assistance 8. At least three interactions and coordination meetings on the implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies, including the CEDAW Committee, action plans for concerned government stakeholders at central and local level are organized 9. Support provided to finalize the NHRAP

-The project supported a two days training to 25 NCJF Secretariat members on the mandate and functions of the CJF at regional and District levels to ensure effective coordination and monitoring of implementation of NCJF actions. -In order to ensure effectiveness of the NCJF, TORs for their operationalization were developed which includes terms of Reference for meetings and information sharing protocols between justice institutions -Support has been extended for development of the National Prosecution Service Five-year Strategic Plan (2019 – 2023) and the first draft of the plan has been finalized. -The project has supported procurement of two vehicles for the DPPs office and CHRAGG to facilitate monitoring and inspection of places of detention across the country, all procurement processes has been completed and vehicles are expected early January 2020 - The project has successful supported the development of legal aid code of conduct which was launched in April 2019 during the National legal aid symposium, however, some improvements were recommended and are expected to be completed by April 2020. - Three interaction meetings at technical level on implementation of UPR and other Treaty Bodies were conducted in Zanzibar and mainland where an implementation and monitoring plan for recommendations was developed - Support has been extended to develop the NHRAP which is at final stages, validation at technical and ministry level has been completed and now waiting for approval from the parliamentary standing committee on constitutional affairs.

- Legal Aid sector oversight and coordination mechanisms strengthened for better quality service delivery and appropriate referral system - Support to establishment of Sheria Television - Support planning, orientation, capacity building on programme broadcasting and development of TV programs
